author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: For micro-organisms to be able to grow, a grow culture must satisfy all of the following requirements: provide an energy source, fulfil nutritional needs: mineral ions, growth factors, and provide a steady pH and ionic force close to optimum values.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Here we look at how to transform bacteria with new plasmids. Transformation is the act of introducing a DNA sequence into the cells. We use chemocompetent cells in this case, a strain commonly used is DH5α.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: For this process we will try to get one plasmid to pass into another strain. This can be done for different reasons including: testing conjugative capacity, and preparing for a λred recombination.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Often used for linearising plasmids or testing the presense and size of either an insert and or a restriction site. This is useful as it is a simple process and does not require anything else other than the enzyme and the DNA product; which can come directly from a DNA extraction.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: For this step you will need a large biomass of cells in order to be able to extract a useful quantity of genetic materia. The ideal way to obtain large quantities of cells, is by y Lysogeny broth culture. This culture can be used for DNA extraction, here we will be using ENZA Plasmid DNA Mini Kit I by Omega Bio-Tek.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Here we will take a plasmid, pAPT110 as an example, and cut it with the Nhe1 restriction enzyme. The cut is being made just before the KmR cassette as seen in the image below.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: The sequencing preparation is to be done in the following way with the company EuroFins. It is extremely important to take note of the bar code for each tube, and what was placed into each tube as we will receive the sequences based on these codes. Only one primer should be placed in each tube. Here is an example of what should be noted:

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Electrophoretic gel purification is a standard electrophoretic assay to migrate DNA in a gel, however after migration is complete we recover and purify specific bands of DNA based on their size.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Here you will find a detailed protocol on electropheretic gel migration. Electropheresis is the process of migrating a sample in a gel. To do this protocol one needs the following at their disposal:

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Glycerol stock prep allows us to store bacterial strains for the long term. In order to do this we must work in sterile conditions and place them into an innert/nutritive environment.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Lambdared (referred to as λred) recombination allows for the insertion of a PCR fragment into a DNA sequence. In order for this process to be done, one needs to linearise the DNA sequence (if plasmid), and then prepare the λred strain which in this case contain the red system in their chromosome and are temperature inducible.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: This procedure is done in order to amplify the biomass of a single bacterial clone. This could then allow us to proceed to different experiments on all identical cells such as: DNA extraction and electrophoretic purification.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Petri dish preparation allows us to create dishes of nutrient rich gel. These gels can then be used to grow bacterial strains on for testing/experimentation in the lab.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Petri dish smears should follow a specific protocol. This in order to evenly spread the cells over a nutrient rich gel. Depending on what is being done we could be trying to isolate certain strains or just test them against an antibiotic.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Subcloning can be done for a variety of reasons, here are just two: testing antibiotic resistances for a certain strain, and wanting to smear a strain in order to obtain isolated colonies.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: Recombination by InFusion allows for the insertion of PCR fragments or other DNA fragments into a plasmid; all this without having to linearise the plasmid. Moreover InFusion allows for the insertion of multiple sequences at once, and it all takes about 1h.

author: Dereck de Mezquita
summary: This protocol will allow you to amplify desired sequences, by use of specific primers, and a thermocycler. This allows us to have these sequences in greater quantities and allow us future experiments.
